definition[0]: feeling strong emotions which make you want to shout at someone or hurt them because they have behaved in an unfair, cruel, offensive etc way, or because you think that a situation is unfair, unacceptable etc
example[0]: I was angry because he hadn’t told me his plans.
example[1]: He was beginning to get angry.
example[2]: His comments brought an angry response from opposition politicians.
example[3]: ‘Calm down, ’ she said, looking at his angry face.
example[4]: Jesse laughed, which made me even angrier.
example[5]: ‘Please don’t be angry with me, ’ she said.
example[6]: They are angry at the way they have been treated.
example[7]: Kate’s still so angry about the whole thing.
example[8]: The workers are angry that they haven’t been paid for the week.
definition[1]: an angry sky or cloud looks dark and stormy
definition[2]: an angry wound etc is painful and red and looks infected
explanation[0]: You say that someone is angry with another person
example[9]: My parents were very angry with me
bad_example[0]: My parents were angry to me
explanation[1]: You say that someone is  angry about something
example[10]: I was really angry about what had happened
explanation[2]: that someone is angry at someone, or angry at something
example[11]: Please don’t get angry at me
example[12]: I was really angry at what had happened
definition[3]: feeling strong emotions because you think someone has behaved badly, or because a situation seems bad or unfair
example[13]: He gets really angry if people keep him waiting.
example[15]: Dad was mad at me for damaging the car.
definition[4]: rather angry – used when speaking to people you know well
example[16]: She was cross with me for being late.
example[17]: I was annoyed no one had told me the class was cancelled.
definition[6]: annoyed and impatient, especially by something that keeps happening or something someone keeps saying
example[18]: I was irritated by their stupid questions.
example[21]: He’s always bad-tempered when he doesn’t get what he wants.
definition[8]: feeling a little angry for a period of time, often for no particular reason
example[22]: I woke up in a bad mood.
example[23]: She’s been in a foul mood all morning.
definition[9]: in an angry mood for a short time, especially because someone has just said something to offend or annoy you
example[24]: He walked off in a huff when they refused to let him join in their game.
display[8]: somebody has got up on the wrong side of the bed
definition[10]: used when you think someone has been in an angry mood all day, for no particular reason – often used humorously
example[25]: I don’t know what’s wrong – she must have got up on the wrong side of the bed today.
example[26]: She was furious when she found out he’d been lying to her.
definition[11]: very angry and shocked by something you think is unfair or wrong
example[28]: Most people were outraged by the 9/11 attacks.
definition[12]: extremely angry – used mainly in writing, for example in newspaper reports
example[30]: Gordon Brown was reported to be incandescent with rage over the article.
definition[13]: to suddenly become very angry and start shouting at someone
example[31]: It was the first time I’d seen her lose her temper.
